questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Colossians 1:1-25 aloud, focusing on the declarations about Christ's supremacy and creation.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'He is' (referring to Christ) that emphasizes His role in all things
Pay attention to the majestic tone and the contrast between the 'domain of darkness' and the 'kingdom of His beloved Son' (v.13)
The phrase 'all things were created through Him' appears in verse 16 and is a key declaration

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Paul and the church in Colossae) does WHAT (affirms Christ's supremacy) WHERE (in the heavenly realm) and WHY (to counter false teachings that elevate other things above Christ).
tips: Include Paul's role as the apostle who writes to the church in Colossae
Note that Christ is the head of the church and the one through whom all things were created
The church was being influenced by false teachings about the nature of Christ and the gospel

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Christ as the image of the invisible God (v.15), all things created through Him (v.16), or the fullness of God dwelling in Him (v.19)?
tips: The phrase 'image of the invisible God' reveals Christ as the true and visible representation of God
The declaration that 'all things were created through Him and for Him' shows the cosmic scope of Christ's authority
The fullness of God dwelling in Christ means that He is the complete and sufficient mediator of all things

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Colossae through this passage?
tips: Paul's goal was to ensure the church did not be distracted by false teachings about Christ or other things
The passage emphasizes that Christ is the only one who has authority over all creation and redemption
This is crucial for the Colossian church to maintain their focus on Christ as the center of their faith

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The title 'firstborn of all creation', the phrase 'all things were created through Him', or the concept of 'reconciling all things'?
tips: 'Firstborn' refers to Christ's preeminent position in creation, not that He was born first in time
The phrase 'for Him' means that all creation exists to honor and serve Christ's purpose
'Reconciling all things' means that Christ has restored the broken relationship between God and creation through His death and resurrection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does Christ being the head of the church (v.18) impact your life this week? What practical step can you take to live in unity with the church?
tips: When you feel the church is divided, remember that Christ is the head who reconciles us to God and each other
Pray for the church to be united in the gospel and not be distracted by false teachings
This week, actively seek to build unity in your small group or church community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for Christ as the head of the church and the one who reconciles all things. Ask for the strength to live in His supremacy.
tips: Thank God that He has reconciled us to Himself through Christ
Pray for the church to be united and focused on Christ rather than false teachings
Ask God to help you live in the reality that Christ is the head of all creation and the center of your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Colossians 2:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the emphasis on Christ as the fullness of deity and the nailing of the record of debt to the cross.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'in Him' (v.9, 10, 14, 15)
Pay attention to the phrase 'fullness of deity' in verse 9
Note the contrast between 'plausible arguments' (v.4) and 'Christ' (v.10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being taught, WHAT Paul emphasizes, WHERE this teaching occurs, and WHY he writes this passage.
tips: Include the church in Colossae as the audience
Note that Paul emphasizes Christ as the fullness of deity and the source of all wisdom
Mention the context of false teachings (philosophy and empty deceit) that Paul wants to address

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the fullness of deity dwelling in Christ (v.9), the record of debt nailed to the cross (v.14), or the disarming of rulers and authorities (v.15)?
tips: The phrase 'the whole fullness of deity dwells bodily in Him' (v.9) is a profound statement about Christ's nature
The act of 'nailing the record of debt to the cross' (v.14) shows the complete settlement of sin
The disarming of 'rulers and authorities' (v.15) illustrates Christ's victory over all opposition

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Colossae through this passage?
tips: Paul wants them to know that Christ alone holds all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge
He is defending the sufficiency of Christ against false teachings that might lead them astray
The passage emphasizes that we are fully reconciled to God through Christ, not through human traditions or philosophies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'fullness of deity', the meaning of 'circumcision made without hands', and the 'elemental spirits of the world'?
tips: 'Fullness of deity' refers to the complete and total nature of God dwelling in Christ (v.9)
'Circumcision made without hands' (v.12) means being made whole in Christ, not by human ritual but by the work of Christ
'Elemental spirits of the world' (v.2) refers to the basic forces of the world that are opposed to Christ, as opposed to the spiritual forces of God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live in Christ alone this week, as Paul encourages the church in Colossae to be rooted and built up in Him?
tips: Choose one area where you might be relying on your own efforts or traditions instead of Christ
Practice 'being rooted and built up in Him' by spending time in prayer and fellowship with other believers
Reflect on what it means to be 'circumcised with a circumcision made without hands' (v.12) - how does that apply to your life?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the fullness of Christ and ask for His strength to live by Him alone.
tips: Thank God for the complete and fullness of Christ that saves us
Pray for the church in Colossae to be united in Christ and free from false teachings
Ask God to help you live in the reality that Christ is the fullness of deity and that all your needs are met in Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Colossians 3:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'raised with Christ', 'life hidden with Christ in God', and the repeated call to 'put off' and 'put on'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'raised with Christ' (v.1) is foundational and repeated throughout the chapter
Pay attention to the emotional shift from the old self to the new self (v.5-10) as a transformation
The phrase 'Christ is all, and in all' (v.15) is a powerful statement of unity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the church in Colossae is being called to, WHAT they must do (put off the old self and put on the new), WHERE this transformation happens (spiritually), and WHY (because they have been raised with Christ).
tips: Include the key event of being raised with Christ (v.1)
Note the call to set their minds on things above (v.1)
Describe the promise of appearing with Christ in glory (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Christ is all, and in all' (v.15), 'put on love which binds everything together in perfect harmony' (v.14), or the peace of Christ ruling in their hearts (v.15).
tips: 'Christ is all, and in all' (v.15) is a radical statement of unity that transcends ethnic and social boundaries
The call to 'put on love' (v.14) is the ultimate goal of the entire passage, binding all other virtues together
The peace of Christ ruling in their hearts (v.15) provides the foundation for unity and reconciliation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Colossae about their identity and life as those raised with Christ?
tips: Paul emphasizes that the church in Colossae must live in the reality of being raised with Christ (v.1), which transforms their entire identity
The theological significance is that their life is hidden with Christ in God (v.4), meaning they are not in the world but in the heavenly reality
This passage refutes false teachings that might have been influencing the Colossian church (e.g., Jewish legalism, pagan practices)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'life hidden with Christ in God' (v.4), the list of things to put off (v.5-10), or the statement 'Christ is all, and in all' (v.15)?
tips: 'Life hidden with Christ in God' (v.4) means that their identity is not in their earthly actions but in their union with Christ
The list of things to put off (v.5-10) includes behaviors that are common in the culture of Colossae (e.g., anger, covetousness) but the scope of 'put off' is comprehensive
'Christ is all, and in all' (v.15) is a radical statement that the church is unified in Christ, not by human efforts but by divine grace

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: As you have been raised with Christ, what specific action can you take this week to live in the unity of Christ (as described in v.15) and put on love?
tips: Identify one person in your life who you can show love and forgiveness to, as Paul encourages
Practice 'ruling in your heart' the peace of Christ (v.15) by seeking reconciliation in a conflict
Consider how your actions reflect the unity of Christ (v.15) in your daily interactions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that we have been raised with Christ and that He is all in all. Ask for the strength to live in unity and love.
tips: Thank God for raising us with Christ and for the new life we have in Him
Pray for the grace to put off the old self and put on the new self (v.5-10)
Ask God to help us live in the unity of Christ (v.15) and to be a church that reflects His love

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Colossians 4:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'Continue steadfastly in prayer' and the repeated emphasis on prayer and thanksgiving.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Continue steadfastly in prayer' appears in verse 1
Pay attention to the word 'prayer' being used 5 times in the chapter
The emotional tone shifts from urgency (prayer) to encouragement (greetings)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is encouraged to continue in prayer, WHAT they are to do, WHERE this prayer is to be offered, and WHY Paul emphasizes it.
tips: Paul is writing to the church in Colossae
The church is to continue in prayer with watchfulness and thanksgiving
This prayer is to be offered to God in the context of Paul's imprisonment

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the command to continue in prayer (v.1-2), the grace of God in the midst of suffering (v.5-6), or the practical advice on speech (v.6-7)?
tips: Paul's imprisonment is a powerful context for prayer - he is in chains but still praying
The phrase 'seasoned with salt' in v.6 is a metaphor for speech that is both flavorful and enduring
The name of Tychicus as a messenger shows the connection between Paul and the church

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Colossae through this passage about continuing in prayer?
tips: Paul is in prison for declaring the mystery of Christ, so he is praying for the church to be mature in the faith
The prayer life is a response to the gospel and a means of spiritual growth
Paul wants the church to be grounded in the mystery of Christ, not in philosophies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The prison context, the meaning of 'seasoned with salt', or the role of the names listed (Tychicus, Onesimus, etc.)?
tips: Paul's imprisonment is a unique context - he is in chains but still praying, which shows the power of prayer in suffering
'Seasoned with salt' is a metaphor from the Old Testament for speech that is both flavorful and enduring (not just sweet but also preserving)
The list of names (Tychicus, Onesimus, etc.) is a way for Paul to build fellowship and encourage the church

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of continuing in prayer to your life this week?
tips: Set a specific time each day to pray with watchfulness and thanksgiving
Pray for the church in Colossae (or a specific church in your life) as Paul did
Pray for the mystery of Christ to be understood in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the power of prayer and ask for courage to continue in prayer even when life is difficult.
tips: Thank God for Paul's example of prayer in prison
Pray for the church in Colossae to be mature in the faith
Ask God to help you pray with watchfulness and thanksgiving
